attributes.title: Replication of Experiment 1 from 'Confidence as a priority signal' (Aguilar-Lleyda, Lemarchand & de Gardelle)

item1.value:
The experiment we want to replicate is Experiment 1 from the study described in the following preprint: https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/480350v3

  . The original study aims at finding empirical support for a simple hypothesis. Namely, that, when having to complete different tasks, people prioritize those tasks in which they have more confidence. Experiment 1 focuses on showing that such prioritization happens in situations of retrospective confidence: that is, when reporting tasks already completed.

On each trial of the experiment, participants see an array of Os and Xs, colored blue or orange. After the stimulus is removed they have to complete two tasks: the color task, consisting in reporting whether there were more orange or blue elements, and the letter task, consisting in reporting whether there were more Os or Xs. They do so by using a response screen. Importantly, participants can choose the order in which to complete the tasks: first the color task and then the letter task, or vice versa. After completing both tasks, participants have to rate their confidence on each of them. Also importantly, on each trial the difficulty of each of the tasks is manipulated independently: this can be hard (60% expected performance) or easy (90% expected performance). This means that we have four types of trials: a) hard color - hard letter; b) hard color - easy letter; c) easy color - hard letter; d) easy color - easy letter.

All the effects that we will attempt to replicate relate to the prioritization of one task over another. We expect the task that is answered to first to be linked to higher confidence (as evidenced by confidence reports) than the task that is answered to second.

The specific results we aim at replicating are the following.

1 - Taking, for each participant, the average confidence for first-reported tasks and the average confidence for second-reported tasks, we expect the former to be bigger than the latter, as measured by a paired t-test.

2 - Taking, for each participant, the proportion of trials where the confidence for the first-reported task was bigger than the confidence for the second-reported task, we expect that this proportion will be bigger than 0.5, as assessed by a one-sample, two-sided t-test.

3 - Same as in number 2, but only taking those trials where both tasks have the same difficulty (hard color - hard letter and easy color - easy letter) and where the response for both tasks was correct.

4 - Same as in number 2, but only taking those trials where both tasks have the same difficulty (hard color - hard letter and easy color - easy letter) and where the response for both tasks was an error.

Effects 3 and 4 are crucial, since the corresponding analyses control for difficulty (both tasks have the same) and for performance (both responses were correct (3) or errors (4)). Controlling for these variables ensures that it is not them what drives priority, but confidence.

item2.value:
Although the original study finds clear results, the reduced subset of trials used to calculate effects 3 and 4 diminishes the power of the analyses.  Indeed, when taking the effect size of the four effects described above (as determined by Cohen's d) and running an a priori power analysis to calculate the required sample size, we find out that the original study (N=28) is underpowered for the two final effects. Specifically, if aiming for a (very high) power of 0.95, the required sample sizes are as follow:
Effect #1: 11 participants
Effect #2: 22 participants
Effect #3: 66 participants
Effect #4: 81 participants

Effects #3 and #4 require a sample size much larger than that of the original experiment. Replicating these effects with an adequate sample would throw support for the role of confidence above and beyond difficulty and performance.

item3.value: Cohen's d for the 4 aforementioned effects: #1: 1.214; #2: 0.82; #3: 0.454; #4: 0.406

item6.value: Laboratoire d'Économie Experimentale de Paris, at the Centre d'Économie de la Sorbonne

item8.value: Participants recruited from the participants pool. Mainly, but not necessarily only, university students from the greater Paris area.

item9.value: The tasks from the study were all conducted on a computer.

item11.value: Stimuli, materials and procedures are exactly the same. The actual place where the original study was conducted will be that used for the replication.

item12.value: After giving the instructions, experimenters will be removed from the sight of the participants. However, they will remain in the same room in order to answer to give an answer to any doubt participants may have.

item13.value: There is only one condition within the experiment.

item14.value: The experimenters will be the authors of the present replication study. Therefore, they are aware of their hypotheses. However, the instructions will not bias participants towards fulfilling the hypotheses of the study.

item15.value: At least 81 participants. However, there could easily be more, given that each experimental session can accommodate up to 20 participants. Sessions will be run until achieving the target sample size.

item16.value: 81 participants is the biggest of the sample sizes that our power analyses determined

item24.value: The only difference that the experimenters have introduced is a bigger sample size. This could influence the size of the effect. Since we do not expect the original and the replication samples to be different in terms of any variable relevant for the study, we expect the direction of the effect to be the same.

item26.value: As in the original study, no exclusion criteria are established. Once a participant finishes the study and consents on her data be used, her data will not be removed from the dataset. Within each participant's data, no trials will be removed as an outlier for any of our analyses.

item27.value: The 4 effects that we aim to replicate will be obtained through the same analyses as in the original experiment (and as detailed before in this preregistration form).

item28.value: That where the 4 tested effects remain significant, and in the same direction as in the original study.

registration_responses.item1:
The experiment we want to replicate is Experiment 1 from the study described in the following preprint: https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/480350v3

  . The original study aims at finding empirical support for a simple hypothesis. Namely, that, when having to complete different tasks, people prioritize those tasks in which they have more confidence. Experiment 1 focuses on showing that such prioritization happens in situations of retrospective confidence: that is, when reporting tasks already completed.

On each trial of the experiment, participants see an array of Os and Xs, colored blue or orange. After the stimulus is removed they have to complete two tasks: the color task, consisting in reporting whether there were more orange or blue elements, and the letter task, consisting in reporting whether there were more Os or Xs. They do so by using a response screen. Importantly, participants can choose the order in which to complete the tasks: first the color task and then the letter task, or vice versa. After completing both tasks, participants have to rate their confidence on each of them. Also importantly, on each trial the difficulty of each of the tasks is manipulated independently: this can be hard (60% expected performance) or easy (90% expected performance). This means that we have four types of trials: a) hard color - hard letter; b) hard color - easy letter; c) easy color - hard letter; d) easy color - easy letter.

The specific results we aim at replicating are the following.

1 - Taking, for each participant, the average confidence for first-reported tasks and the average confidence for second-reported tasks, we expect the former to be bigger than the latter, as measured by a paired t-test.

2 - Taking, for each participant, the proportion of trials where the confidence for the first-reported task was bigger than the confidence for the second-reported task, we expect that this proportion will be bigger than 0.5, as assessed by a one-sample, two-sided t-test.

3 - Same as in number 2, but only taking those trials where both tasks have the same difficulty (hard color - hard letter and easy color - easy letter) and where the response for both tasks was correct.

4 - Same as in number 2, but only taking those trials where both tasks have the same difficulty (hard color - hard letter and easy color - easy letter) and where the response for both tasks was an error.

Effects 3 and 4 are crucial, since the corresponding analyses control for difficulty (both tasks have the same) and for performance (both responses were correct (3) or errors (4)). Controlling for these variables ensures that it is not them what drives priority, but confidence.

Indeed, when taking the effect size of the four effects described above (as determined by Cohen's d) and running an a priori power analysis to calculate the required sample size, we find out that the original study (N=28) is underpowered for the two final effects. Specifically, if aiming for a (very high) power of 0.95, the required sample sizes are as follow:
Effect #1: 11 participants

Effect #3: 66 participants
Effect #4: 81 participants

Effects #3 and #4 require a sample size much larger than that of the original experiment. Replicating these effects with an adequate sample would throw support for the role of confidence above and beyond difficulty and performance.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

other.value:
We may look at whether number of years in Canada/US affected individuals' performance/scores (i.e., as a proxy of comprehension), as well as whether individuals report having any neurological impairments. We will also look at whether familiarity with the building in the video played affected their navigation accuracy overall. We will also be examining whether performance on the cognitive tasks varied as a function of individual differences factors (i.e., age, gender, ethnicity)

Although we have started data collection (so far, only 12/200 participants' data have been collected), we have not conducted any analyses on the data set so far.

sample.value: We would like to collect data from a minimum of 200 participants.

analyses.value:
The planned analyses consists of 3 steps
1a) Confirmatory factor analysis on the way finding questionnaire to check if there are indeed 3 subfactors
1b) Check whether the behavioural indicators of navigation ability maps onto self-reported navigation ability (i.e., response on the wayfinding questionnaire)
2) Examine whether there is indeed a significant relation between face processing and navigation
3) Examine the relation between mental rotation and (i) face processing and (ii) navigation

outliers.value: We will be excluding participants who do not report having normal/corrected to normal vision. For the analysis, we may exclude participants who do not score above 80% for the mental rotation task for trials where the items are rotated at 0 degrees and are identical (i.e., an attention check). We will also exclude participants who admitted that they were not paying attention or trying to complete the task properly for that debrief question.

dependent.value:
Wayfinding Questionnaire (van der Ham et al., 2013)
Cambridge face memory task (Duchaine & Nakayama, 2006)
Mental spatial rotation task (Ganis & Kievit, 2014)
Navigation tasks:
-route recall task: We will show participants a recording of a walking route around the building and have them recall the route they took on a map
-landmark position task: we will ask participants to select where the distinctive items (landmarks) in the video walking route were given a different position along the route. 

We additionally will be asking participants to provide their age, gender, ethnicity, and if they have corrected to normal vision. 
At the end of the experiment, we will be asking participants if they had any issues with the study, if they were familiar with the building the video walking route was of, and if they completed the experiment to the best of their abilities.

conditions.value: All participants will complete the same version of this study. There are no experimental conditions.

hypothesis.value:
The primary research questions are to investigate (1) whether there is a significant relation between facial recognition and spatial navigation ability in a normal population and (2) determine underlying cognitive mechanisms for why this relation may exist (3) whether our behavioral measures of navigation correlates positively with their self report.
We hypothesize that facial recognition and spatial navigation will have a positive correlation, and that the common cognitive mechanism underlying both of these phenomena may be higher-order visuospatial processing (e.g., mental rotation).

registration_responses.data: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.
registration_responses.name: Spatial navigation and facial recognition
registration_responses.other:
We may look at whether number of years in Canada/US affected individuals' performance/scores (i.e., as a proxy of comprehension), as well as whether individuals report having any neurological impairments. We will also look at whether familiarity with the building in the video played affected their navigation accuracy overall. We will also be examining whether performance on the cognitive tasks varied as a function of individual differences factors (i.e., age, gender, ethnicity)

Although we have started data collection (so far, only 12/200 participants' data have been collected), we have not conducted any analyses on the data set so far.
registration_responses.sample: We would like to collect data from a minimum of 200 participants.
registration_responses.analyses:
The planned analyses consists of 3 steps
1a) Confirmatory factor analysis on the way finding questionnaire to check if there are indeed 3 subfactors
1b) Check whether the behavioural indicators of navigation ability maps onto self-reported navigation ability (i.e., response on the wayfinding questionnaire)
2) Examine whether there is indeed a significant relation between face processing and navigation
3) Examine the relation between mental rotation and (i) face processing and (ii) navigation
registration_responses.outliers: We will be excluding participants who do not report having normal/corrected to normal vision. For the analysis, we may exclude participants who do not score above 80% for the mental rotation task for trials where the items are rotated at 0 degrees and are identical (i.e., an attention check). We will also exclude participants who admitted that they were not paying attention or trying to complete the task properly for that debrief question.
registration_responses.dependent:
Wayfinding Questionnaire (van der Ham et al., 2013)
Cambridge face memory task (Duchaine & Nakayama, 2006)
Mental spatial rotation task (Ganis & Kievit, 2014)
Navigation tasks:
-route recall task: We will show participants a recording of a walking route around the building and have them recall the route they took on a map
-landmark position task: we will ask participants to select where the distinctive items (landmarks) in the video walking route were given a different position along the route. 

We additionally will be asking participants to provide their age, gender, ethnicity, and if they have corrected to normal vision. 
At the end of the experiment, we will be asking participants if they had any issues with the study, if they were familiar with the building the video walking route was of, and if they completed the experiment to the best of their abilities.
registration_responses.conditions: All participants will complete the same version of this study. There are no experimental conditions.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
The primary research questions are to investigate (1) whether there is a significant relation between facial recognition and spatial navigation ability in a normal population and (2) determine underlying cognitive mechanisms for why this relation may exist (3) whether our behavioral measures of navigation correlates positively with their self report.
We hypothesize that facial recognition and spatial navigation will have a positive correlation, and that the common cognitive mechanism underlying both of these phenomena may be higher-order visuospatial processing (e.g., mental rotation).

attributes.title: Peer Victimization, Friendships, & Health Systematic Review

summary.value: This is a registration of a systematic review protocol prior to conducting the review. The attached file contains the detailed study protocol.

registration_responses.summary: This is a registration of a systematic review protocol prior to conducting the review. The attached file contains the detailed study protocol.

attributes.title: Emotion Recognition and Well-being
attributes.description: We will be conducting an online study through Qualtrics that includes computer tasks and questionnaires. We will be testing whether general well-being predicts how easily a person is able to recognize positive emotion in human facial expressions and whether that effect is mediated by trait positive affect.

q3.value: An online study through Qualtrics that includes computer tasks and questionnaires. The study is primarily being conducted to test another researcher's hypothesis about schizotypy personality. This pre-registration is for a secondary hypothesis of the author's about well-being. Although the data collection is being led by the other researcher, the author will be tangentially involved in the data collection process and is able to summarize the planned study procedures.

q4.value:
1) Positive emotion reactivity to pleasant video stimuli will be associated with general well-being.
2) Positive expression recognition to facial expression stimuli will be associated with general well-being.
3) Both associations will be cross-sectionally mediated by trait positive affect.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study is an observational study without any variable manipulation. The study is cross-sectional and so involves only one timepoint. The study is online and participants will complete all study procedures through the Qualtrics platform on their computer. Participants will complete the study procedures in the following order: 1) half the questionnaires, 2) the facial expression stimuli, 3) the other half of the questionnaires, 4) demographics, 5) the pleasant video stimuli. A PDF of the Qualtrics survey is attached.

q9.value: No randomization is involved in this study

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be college students at a large, state university in the Midwest region of the United States. They will be compensated with course (extra) credit for their undergraduate psychology classes. Participants will be required to be 18 years old and literate in the English language. Students can be traditional or non-traditional students and can live on or off campus.

q13.value:
An exact initial sample size is not specified; however, we are aiming for an initial sample size between 500 and 1000 participants (before excluding participants due to careless responding). The final number will likely depend on how many college students sign up for the study during the semesters/summers it is active.

The questionnaires will include six attention check questions to detect careless responding. The attention check questions will be evenly spaced out throughout the questionnaires. The attention checks will ask participants to select a particular response (e.g., “often true for me”). Any participant who fails one or more attention check questions will be excluded from data analysis. We are anticipating the final sample size will be 25%-33% less than the initial sample size due to this exclusion criteria.

q14.value:
A brief review of the literature on the effect of positive emotion reactivity on general well-being was conducted. The review suggests previous studies testing associations show correlations ranging from +.03 to +.81. As is common in psychological science, effect sizes differ greater, likely due to methodological factors.

It seems that the largest effect sizes are from studies that used neuroimaging to measure positive emotion reactivity. A series of studies examining the association between neuroticism (low well-being) and neural activation of brain pleasure centers in response to a short, positive, film segments resulted in correlations between -.63 and -.81 (Britton, Ho, Taylor, & Liberzon, 2007). A different study testing the association between amygdala neutral reactivity to positive picture stimuli and subjective happiness (high well-being) was +.44 and +.49 (Cunningham & Kirkland, 2013). In another study the correlation from the neutral activation of brain pleasure centers in response to positive picture stimuli with psychological well-being was +.47, while the correlation with cortisol levels was -.32 to -.33 (Heller et al., 2013).

It seems more moderate effect sizes are from studies that used automatic activity to measure positive emotion reactivity. A study found a +.21 correlation between autonomic reactivity indicated by heart rate variability and affect valence when/after viewing positive picture stimuli (Fujimura and Okanoya, 2012). A study testing the association between autonomic reactivity indicated by skin conductance after seeing positive picture stimuli and avoidant attachment (low well-being) found correlations ranging from -.06 to -.38 (Yee & Shiota, 2015).

Effect sizes from studies that used self-report questionnaires to measure positive emotion reactivity were highly variable, ranging from -.15 in the reverse direction to +.45. A study comparing individuals with major depressive disorder (low well-being) to a control group without any depressive disorder (high well-being), found a standardized mean difference of about +1.0 (r = 1.0 / sqrt( 1.0^2 + 4) = +.45) between self-reported affect valence after seeing positive words generated by the participant in an earlier sentence completion task (Avgusta et al., 2005). In addition, a study found that emotional and physical symptoms (low well-being) were not associated (r = +.03) with self-reported happiness ratings after a positive film clip (Dawkins, Acaster, & Powell, 2007). Yet another study compared individuals with depression disorder (low well-being) to a control group without any depression disorder (high well-being), finding a standardized mean difference of d = (2.48 – 2.91) / ((1.78 + 1.04) / 2) = -.30 (r = -.30 / (sqrt(-.30^2 + 4) = -.15, reverse direction) for happiness in response to a happy film clip, d = (3.53 – 2.93) / ((1.34 + 0.88) / 2) = +.54 (r = +.54 / (sqrt(+.54^2 + 4) = +.26) for pride in response to a pride film clip, and d = (2.79 – 2.39) / ((1.10 + 1.10) / 2) = +.36 (r = +.36 / (sqrt(+.36^2 + 4) = +.18) (Gruber, Oveis, Keltner, & Johnson, 2011). A similar study compared individuals with depression disorder (low well-being) and a control group without any depression disorder (high well-being), finding a standardized mean differences of d = (((6.00 + 5.44) / 2) – 4.76) / ((1.63 + 2.02 + 2.31) / 3) = +.48 (r = .48 / sqrt(.48^2 + 4) = +.23 (Reed, Sayette, & Cohn, 2007).

Britton, J. C., Ho, S. H., Taylor, S. F., & Liberzon, I. (2007). Neuroticism associated with neural activation patterns to positive stimuli. Psychiatry Research: Neuroimaging, 156(3), 263-267.

Cunningham, W. A., & Kirkland, T. (2013). The joyful, yet balanced, amygdala: moderated responses to positive but not negative stimuli in trait happiness. Social Cognitive and Affective Neuroscience, 9(6), 760-766.

Dawkins, L., Acaster, S., & Powell, J. H. (2007). The effects of smoking and abstinence on experience of happiness and sadness in response to positively valenced, negatively valenced, and neutral film clips. Addictive Behaviors, 32(2), 425-431.

Fujimura, T., & Okanoya, K. (2012). Heart rate variability predicts emotional flexibility in response to positive stimuli. Psychology, 3(8), 578-582.

Gruber, J., Oveis, C., Keltner, D., & Johnson, S. L. (2011). A discrete emotions approach to positive emotion disturbance in depression. Cognition and Emotion, 25(1), 40-52.

Heller, A. S., Johnstone, T., Light, S. N., Peterson, M. J., Kolden, G. G., Kalin, N. H., & Davidson, R. J. (2013). Relationships between changes in sustained fronto-striatal connectivity and positive affect in major depression resulting from antidepressant treatment. American Journal of Psychiatry, 170(2), 197–206.

Reed, L. I., Sayette, M. A., & Cohn, J. F. (2007). Impact of depression on response to comedy: A dynamic facial coding analysis. Journal of Abnormal Psychology, 116(4), 804-809.

Shestyuk, A. Y., Deldin, P. J., Brand, J. E., & Deveney, C. M. (2005). Reduced sustained brain activity during processing of positive emotional stimuli in major depression. Biological Psychiatry, 57(10), 1089-1096.

Yee, C. I., & Shiota, M. N. (2015). An insecure base: Attachment style and orienting response to positive stimuli. Psychophysiology, 52(7), 905-909.

Regarding the positive emotion reactivity hypothesis (i.e., Hypothesis 1), the large standardized effect size variability in the existing scientific literature with self-report measures makes it difficult to draw conclusions about what effect size to expect from the population underlying the present study. Therefore, the statistical power for Hypothesis 1 was evaluated for the central range of zero-order correlations for studies using self-report measures: r = .10, r = .20, r = .30, and r = .40. In addition, minimum and maximum expected sample sizes were evaluated: 500 – (500 * .33) = 335 and 1000 – (1000 * .33) = 670. We assume a Type I error rate of .05.

Statistical Power (1 – β)	N = 335	N = 670
r = .10	.45	.74
r = .20	.96	.99
r = .30	.99	.99
r = .40	.99	.99

Regarding the effect of positive expression recognition on general well-being, standardized effect sizes ranged from .00 to .70. A meta-analysis of 18 studies comparing individuals with internalizing disorders to controls on overall facial expression recognition was d = .35 (r = .35 / sqrt(.35^2 + 4) = .17) for anxiety disorders and d = .58 (r = .58 / sqrt(.58^2 + 4) = .28) (Demenescu et al., 2010). However, the meta-analysis did not separate out analyses by discrete emotions. One study found that dispositional joy was weakly uncorrelated with the tendency to correctly recognize pictures of happy faces (r = (.03 + .10) / 2 = .07) and the tendency to incorrectly say pictures of non-happy faces (e.g., neutral) were happy (r = (.07 + .25) /2 = .16). Another study found that individuals with a depression disorder vs a control group were worse at identifying happy facial expressions (Surguladze et al., 2004). The first set of results refer to pictures of faces flashing on the screen for 0.1 second. For 100% happy facial expressions, the tendency to correctly recognize pictures of happy faces was higher in the control group (d = -.22 - -.53 / ((.49 + .12) / 2) = 1.52; r = 1.52 / sqrt(1.52^2 + 4) = .61). For 50% happy facial expressions, the tendency to incorrectly say pictures of non-happy faces (e.g., neutral) were happy was also high in the control group (d = -.41 - -.91 / ((.53 + .24) / 2) = 1.95; r = 1.95 / sqrt(1.95^2 + 4) = .70). The second set of results refer to pictures of faces staying on the screen for 2 seconds. For 100% happy facial expressions, the tendency to correctly recognize pictures of happy faces was higher in the control group (d = (-.15 - -.33) / ((.49 + .12) / 2) = 0.93; r = 0.93 / sqrt(0.93^2 + 4) = .42). For 50% happy facial expressions, the tendency to incorrectly say pictures of non-happy faces (e.g., neutral) were happy was also high in the control group (d = -.26 - -.55 / ((.49 + .16) / 2) = 1.43; r = 1.43 / sqrt(1.43^2 + 4) = .58).

Two similar studies found a non-significant difference between a depressed group and control group on happy facial expression recognition, although the effect size point estimate were meaningful: 1 - (d = (92.2- 87.5) / ((13.4 + 8.4) / 2) = .43, r = .43 / sqrt(.43^2 + 4) = .21) (Leppanen et al., 2004); 2 - (d = ((.82 - .80) + (.82 - .78)) / 2) / ((.07 + .07 + .07 + .06) / 4) = .44, r = .44 / sqrt(.44^2 + 4) = .21) (Milders et al., 2010). In addition, one study found no difference between a depressed group and a control group on happiness facial expression recognition. In the first study, for happy faces, % accuracy was 68.7 in each group (d = 68.7 – 68.7 / ((22.4 + 21.6) / 2) = 0.00, r = 0.00) (Csukly et al., 2009). Three older studies did not report enough statistical information to calculate a correlation coefficient. One did not find any significant differences between happiness facial expression recognition for those with high anxiety (low well-being) and those with low anxiety (high well-being) (Surcinelli et al., 2006). The two other study did find significant differences between happiness facial expression recognition for those with high depression (low well-being) and those with low depression (high well-being) (Mikhailova et al., 1996; Rubinow & Post, 1992). 

Csukly, G., Czobor, P., Szily, E., Takács, B., & Simon, L. (2009). Facial expression recognition in depressed subjects: the impact of intensity level and arousal dimension. The Journal of Nervous and Mental Disease, 197(2), 98-103.

Demenescu, L. R., Kortekaas, R., den Boer, J. A., & Aleman, A. (2010). Impaired attribution of emotion to facial expressions in anxiety and major depression. PloS one, 5(12), e15058.

Leppänen, J. M., Milders, M., Bell, J. S., Terriere, E., & Hietanen, J. K. (2004). Depression biases the recognition of emotionally neutral faces. Psychiatry Research, 128(2), 123-133.

Mikhailova, E. S., Vladimirova, T. V., Iznak, A. F., Tsusulkovskaya, E. J., & Sushko, N. V. (1996). Abnormal recognition of facial expression of emotions in depressed patients with major depression disorder and schizotypal personality disorder. Biological Psychiatry, 40(8), 697-705.

Milders, M., Bell, S., Platt, J., Serrano, R., & Runcie, O. (2010). Stable expression recognition abnormalities in unipolar depression. Psychiatry Research, 179(1), 38-42.

Rubinow, D. R., & Post, R. M. (1992). Impaired recognition of affect in facial expression in depressed patients. Biological Psychiatry, 31(9), 947-953.

Surcinelli, P., Codispoti, M., Montebarocci, O., Rossi, N., & Baldaro, B. (2006). Facial emotion recognition in trait anxiety. Journal of Anxiety Disorders, 20(1), 110-117.

Surguladze, S. A., Young, A. W., Senior, C., Brébion, G., Travis, M. J., & Phillips, M. L. (2004). Recognition accuracy and response bias to happy and sad facial expressions in patients with major depression. Neuropsychology, 18(2), 212-218.

Toner, H. L., & Gates, G. R. (1985). Emotional traits and recognition of facial expression of emotion. Journal of Nonverbal Behavior, 9(1), 48-66.

Regarding the positive expression recognition hypothesis (i.e., Hypothesis 2), the large standardized effect size variability in the existing scientific literature makes it difficult to draw conclusions about what effect size to expect from the population underlying the present study. The larger effect sizes are likely a result of extreme group designs comparing individuals with a depression diagnosis and those without many symptoms. Since our study is not using an extreme groups design, we would not expect the larger correlations of r = .50 and above. Therefore, the statistical power for Hypothesis 2 was evaluated for the central range of zero-order correlations for studies using self-report measures: r = .10, r = .20, r = .30, and r = .40. In addition, minimum and maximum expected sample sizes were evaluated: 500 – (500 * .33) = 335 and 1000 – (1000 * .33) = 670. We assume a Type I error rate of .05.

Statistical Power (1 – β)	N = 335	N = 670
r = .10	.45	.74
r = .20	.96	.99
r = .30	.99	.99
r = .40	.99	.99

q15.value: After one semester/summer of data collection, if we do not have at least 500 participants, we will do another round of data collection the following semester/summer. We will continue data collection each semester/summer until we have at least 500 participants by the end of that semester/summer. Once we have more than 500 participants after the end of a semester/summer, data collection will stop.

question.value: No manipulated variables are involved in this study

Positive emotion reactivity will be measured by reactions to pleasant video stimuli. Participants will view two brief videos on their computer screen (~ 3 minutes each). The two videos will be randomized to prevent confounding by order effects. Before and after watching each video, participants will report how intensely they are currently experiencing 15 different emotions, with the 8 positive emotions being used (7 ordinal response options). I will refer to this as the state positive emotion questionnaire.

Positive expression recognition will be measured by appraisals to facial expression stimuli Participants will view 45 pictures, each 4 times, on their computer screen. The 45*4 = 180 pictures will be randomized to prevent confounding by order effects. After seeing each picture, participants will report whether the facial expression is "pleasant" or "unpleasant" (2 binary response options).

Life satisfaction will be measured by the Riverside Satisfaction with Life Scale questionnaire (7 ordinal response options).

Subjective happiness will be measured by the Subjective Happiness Scale questionnaire (7 ordinal response options).

Depressed mood will be measured by the Depressed Affect subscale from the Center for Epidemiological Study of Depression questionnaire (4 ordinal response options).

Trait positive affect will be measured two different ways as a methodological sensitivity test. First, a questionnaire created by the study principle investigator. It is similar to the PANAS and includes 15 emotion adjectives as items (8 positive emotion items will be used) and frequency of emotional experience in the past month as 7 ordinal response options. I will refer to this as the trait positive affect questionnaire. Second, the Dispositional Positive Emotions scale which asks about general frequency and intensity of 7 different positive emotions with 7 ordinal response options.

Positive emotion reactivity will be quantified as the difference in state positive emotion from before and after the videos. The 7 response options for state positive emotion will be numerically coded from 0 to 6. Observed scores will be created by averaging the item response codes and then converting them to percentage of maximum possible (POMP) units to enhance interpretation. Final reactivity scores will be residuals from a simple linear regression of state positive emotion before the first video predicting the average of state positive emotion after the first and second video. A residualized difference score rather than a raw difference score will be used because raw difference scores still contain variance from the subtrahend (i.e., state positive emotion before the videos). As a statistical sensitivity check, data analysis will also be conducted using raw difference scores.

Positive expression recognition will be quantified as minus the average percentage of happiness facial expression morph for pictures that the participant rates as pleasant. Each picture is a morph of a different facial expression, including happiness expression and various negative emotion expressions. Each picture has a percentage of happiness expression associated with it. These percentages will be averaged together, for those pictures that the participant rated as pleasant. The minus of the average percentage is used such that higher values correspond to greater positive expression recognition.

Item responses from each questionnaire will be used to create unit-weighted total scores. The response options will be numerically coded from 0 to 6 for the 7 response option questionnaires (Riverside Life Satisfaction Scale, Subjective Happiness Scale, trait positive affect) and 0 to 3 for the 4 response options questionnaires (Center for Epidemiological Study of Depression – Depressed Affect subscale). Any negatively valanced items will be reverse coded. Total scores will be created by averaging the item response codes and then converted them to percentage of maximum possible (POMP) units to enhance interpretation.

Regarding the Dispositional Positive Emotions scale, because the original scale development paper found a wide range of inter-subscale correlations from r = .05 to r = .75, we will conduct psychometric tests of the questionnaire to determine an appropriate total score (e.g., exclude certain subscales). Specifically, we will use the omega hierarchical reliability coefficient from a bifactor model to make determinations.

Structural equation modeling (SEM) will be conducted with the `lavaan` R package. Three separate models will be tested: 1) positive emotion reactivity as the predictor, 2) positive expression recognition as the predictor, 3) both positive emotion reactivity and positive expression recognition as simultaneous predictors with the two different measures of trait positive affect: 1) Trait positive affect questionnaire, 2) Dispositional Positive Emotions scale, resulting in six total SEMs. Neither of the predictors will have a measurement model, but rather be singular manifest variables. The mediator of trait positive affect will also not have a measurement model and be a singular manifest variable. The outcome of general well-being will have a latent measurement model with life satisfaction, subjective happiness, and depressed mood as three manifest indicators.

A-paths, B-paths, and Cprime-paths will be specified. No covaried errors between the general well-being indicators and the mediator or predictor(s) will be specified. The estimator will be full information maximum likelihood (FIML) to account for any missing data and confidence intervals will be computed via bootstrapping (including for the indirect effects). Model fit will be assessed via the CFI, TLI, RSMEA, and SRMR. Re-specification based on modification indices will only be considered if a model fit index is less than the following (arbitrary) cutoffs: CFI < .80; TLI < .80; RMSEA > .15; SRMR > .15. The author has a preference for sticking with a priori specified SEM models and not re-specifying them based on modification indices – hence the relatively low model fit index cutoffs.

q20.value:
In addition to the unstandardized regression coefficients computed by the optimization algorithm, an unstandardized indirect effect and total effect will be calculated as post-estimation transformations. Unstandardized indirect effects will equal A-path unstandardized regression coefficient * B-path unstandardized regression coefficient. Unstandardized total effects will equal Unstandardized indirect effect + Cprime-path (i.e., direct effects are equal to Cprime-path unstandardized regression coefficients). The `lavaan` R package allows for bootstrapping on the post-estimation transformations; therefore, the confidence interval of the unstandardized indirect effects and total effects will also be computed via bootstrapping.

Standardized versions of each effect size will also be calculated via post-estimation transformations. The standardized regression coefficients will equal = unstandardized regression coefficient * standard deviation of the predictor / standard deviation of the outcome. The standardized indirect effect will equal = standardized A-path * standardized B-path. The standardized total effect will equal = standardized indirect effect + standardized Cprime-path. Again, the confidence intervals will be computed via bootstrapping within `lavaan`.

q21.value: Statistical inference will be based on "The New Statistics" by Geoff Cummings. In contrast to null hypothesis statistical testing (NHST), “The New Statistics” focuses on effect size point estimates and their associated confidence intervals: 95% confidence intervals will be reported. Effect size values within the 95% confidence interval are considered plausible population parameter values, with the point estimate being the most likely value.

q22.value: All data for a participant will be excluded if they fail any of 6 attention check items interspersed throughout the survey (see the Sample Size section). As a statistical sensitivity check, data analysis will also be conducted where all data for a participant will only be excluded if they fail all 6 attention check items.

q23.value: Participants must have observed data for at least 50% of the components (e.g., items) of the final composite score, otherwise the score will be coded as missing. For example, is a participant responds to one video, but not the other, their final composite score would still be included. Or is a participant responded to two of the four Subjective Happiness Scale items, their final composite score would still be included. However, if the participant responded to less than 90 of the facial expression stimuli, then their final composite score would be coded as missing. Missing data at the score level will be handled by the FIML estimator within the SEM (see the Statistical Model section).

q24.value: We will explore any differences in effects across the state positive emotions. Although the confirmatory hypothesis will involve averaging all the state positive emotion items, exploratory analyses will test the individual positive emotions in isolation to see if one or two emotions are driving the effect. We will also explore any differences in effects across the videos. Although the confirmatory hypothesis will involve averaging across the two videos, exploratory analyses will test whether effect sizes are larger for one video or another. Exploratory analyses will also test whether particular positive emotions from one video versus the other have differential effects. For example, amusement – but not contentment – in response to the first video will have a strong indirect effect, but amusement in response to the second video will have a weak indirect effect.

registration_responses.q3: An online study through Qualtrics that includes computer tasks and questionnaires. The study is primarily being conducted to test another researcher's hypothesis about schizotypy personality. This pre-registration is for a secondary hypothesis of the author's about well-being. Although the data collection is being led by the other researcher, the author will be tangentially involved in the data collection process and is able to summarize the planned study procedures.
registration_responses.q4:
1) Positive emotion reactivity to pleasant video stimuli will be associated with general well-being.
2) Positive expression recognition to facial expression stimuli will be associated with general well-being.
3) Both associations will be cross-sectionally mediated by trait positive affect.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q9: No randomization is involved in this study
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13:
An exact initial sample size is not specified; however, we are aiming for an initial sample size between 500 and 1000 participants (before excluding participants due to careless responding). The final number will likely depend on how many college students sign up for the study during the semesters/summers it is active.

The questionnaires will include six attention check questions to detect careless responding. The attention check questions will be evenly spaced out throughout the questionnaires. The attention checks will ask participants to select a particular response (e.g., “often true for me”). Any participant who fails one or more attention check questions will be excluded from data analysis. We are anticipating the final sample size will be 25%-33% less than the initial sample size due to this exclusion criteria.
registration_responses.q14:
A brief review of the literature on the effect of positive emotion reactivity on general well-being was conducted. The review suggests previous studies testing associations show correlations ranging from +.03 to +.81. As is common in psychological science, effect sizes differ greater, likely due to methodological factors.

It seems that the largest effect sizes are from studies that used neuroimaging to measure positive emotion reactivity. A series of studies examining the association between neuroticism (low well-being) and neural activation of brain pleasure centers in response to a short, positive, film segments resulted in correlations between -.63 and -.81 (Britton, Ho, Taylor, & Liberzon, 2007). A different study testing the association between amygdala neutral reactivity to positive picture stimuli and subjective happiness (high well-being) was +.44 and +.49 (Cunningham & Kirkland, 2013). In another study the correlation from the neutral activation of brain pleasure centers in response to positive picture stimuli with psychological well-being was +.47, while the correlation with cortisol levels was -.32 to -.33 (Heller et al., 2013).

It seems more moderate effect sizes are from studies that used automatic activity to measure positive emotion reactivity. A study found a +.21 correlation between autonomic reactivity indicated by heart rate variability and affect valence when/after viewing positive picture stimuli (Fujimura and Okanoya, 2012). A study testing the association between autonomic reactivity indicated by skin conductance after seeing positive picture stimuli and avoidant attachment (low well-being) found correlations ranging from -.06 to -.38 (Yee & Shiota, 2015).

Effect sizes from studies that used self-report questionnaires to measure positive emotion reactivity were highly variable, ranging from -.15 in the reverse direction to +.45. A study comparing individuals with major depressive disorder (low well-being) to a control group without any depressive disorder (high well-being), found a standardized mean difference of about +1.0 (r = 1.0 / sqrt( 1.0^2 + 4) = +.45) between self-reported affect valence after seeing positive words generated by the participant in an earlier sentence completion task (Avgusta et al., 2005). In addition, a study found that emotional and physical symptoms (low well-being) were not associated (r = +.03) with self-reported happiness ratings after a positive film clip (Dawkins, Acaster, & Powell, 2007). Yet another study compared individuals with depression disorder (low well-being) to a control group without any depression disorder (high well-being), finding a standardized mean difference of d = (2.48 – 2.91) / ((1.78 + 1.04) / 2) = -.30 (r = -.30 / (sqrt(-.30^2 + 4) = -.15, reverse direction) for happiness in response to a happy film clip, d = (3.53 – 2.93) / ((1.34 + 0.88) / 2) = +.54 (r = +.54 / (sqrt(+.54^2 + 4) = +.26) for pride in response to a pride film clip, and d = (2.79 – 2.39) / ((1.10 + 1.10) / 2) = +.36 (r = +.36 / (sqrt(+.36^2 + 4) = +.18) (Gruber, Oveis, Keltner, & Johnson, 2011). A similar study compared individuals with depression disorder (low well-being) and a control group without any depression disorder (high well-being), finding a standardized mean differences of d = (((6.00 + 5.44) / 2) – 4.76) / ((1.63 + 2.02 + 2.31) / 3) = +.48 (r = .48 / sqrt(.48^2 + 4) = +.23 (Reed, Sayette, & Cohn, 2007).

Britton, J. C., Ho, S. H., Taylor, S. F., & Liberzon, I. (2007). Neuroticism associated with neural activation patterns to positive stimuli. Psychiatry Research: Neuroimaging, 156(3), 263-267.

Cunningham, W. A., & Kirkland, T. (2013). The joyful, yet balanced, amygdala: moderated responses to positive but not negative stimuli in trait happiness. Social Cognitive and Affective Neuroscience, 9(6), 760-766.

Dawkins, L., Acaster, S., & Powell, J. H. (2007). The effects of smoking and abstinence on experience of happiness and sadness in response to positively valenced, negatively valenced, and neutral film clips. Addictive Behaviors, 32(2), 425-431.

Fujimura, T., & Okanoya, K. (2012). Heart rate variability predicts emotional flexibility in response to positive stimuli. Psychology, 3(8), 578-582.

Gruber, J., Oveis, C., Keltner, D., & Johnson, S. L. (2011). A discrete emotions approach to positive emotion disturbance in depression. Cognition and Emotion, 25(1), 40-52.

Heller, A. S., Johnstone, T., Light, S. N., Peterson, M. J., Kolden, G. G., Kalin, N. H., & Davidson, R. J. (2013). Relationships between changes in sustained fronto-striatal connectivity and positive affect in major depression resulting from antidepressant treatment. American Journal of Psychiatry, 170(2), 197–206.

Reed, L. I., Sayette, M. A., & Cohn, J. F. (2007). Impact of depression on response to comedy: A dynamic facial coding analysis. Journal of Abnormal Psychology, 116(4), 804-809.

Shestyuk, A. Y., Deldin, P. J., Brand, J. E., & Deveney, C. M. (2005). Reduced sustained brain activity during processing of positive emotional stimuli in major depression. Biological Psychiatry, 57(10), 1089-1096.

Yee, C. I., & Shiota, M. N. (2015). An insecure base: Attachment style and orienting response to positive stimuli. Psychophysiology, 52(7), 905-909.

Regarding the positive emotion reactivity hypothesis (i.e., Hypothesis 1), the large standardized effect size variability in the existing scientific literature with self-report measures makes it difficult to draw conclusions about what effect size to expect from the population underlying the present study. Therefore, the statistical power for Hypothesis 1 was evaluated for the central range of zero-order correlations for studies using self-report measures: r = .10, r = .20, r = .30, and r = .40. In addition, minimum and maximum expected sample sizes were evaluated: 500 – (500 * .33) = 335 and 1000 – (1000 * .33) = 670. We assume a Type I error rate of .05.

Statistical Power (1 – β)	N = 335	N = 670
r = .10	.45	.74
r = .20	.96	.99
r = .30	.99	.99
r = .40	.99	.99

Regarding the effect of positive expression recognition on general well-being, standardized effect sizes ranged from .00 to .70. A meta-analysis of 18 studies comparing individuals with internalizing disorders to controls on overall facial expression recognition was d = .35 (r = .35 / sqrt(.35^2 + 4) = .17) for anxiety disorders and d = .58 (r = .58 / sqrt(.58^2 + 4) = .28) (Demenescu et al., 2010). However, the meta-analysis did not separate out analyses by discrete emotions. One study found that dispositional joy was weakly uncorrelated with the tendency to correctly recognize pictures of happy faces (r = (.03 + .10) / 2 = .07) and the tendency to incorrectly say pictures of non-happy faces (e.g., neutral) were happy (r = (.07 + .25) /2 = .16). Another study found that individuals with a depression disorder vs a control group were worse at identifying happy facial expressions (Surguladze et al., 2004). The first set of results refer to pictures of faces flashing on the screen for 0.1 second. For 100% happy facial expressions, the tendency to correctly recognize pictures of happy faces was higher in the control group (d = -.22 - -.53 / ((.49 + .12) / 2) = 1.52; r = 1.52 / sqrt(1.52^2 + 4) = .61). For 50% happy facial expressions, the tendency to incorrectly say pictures of non-happy faces (e.g., neutral) were happy was also high in the control group (d = -.41 - -.91 / ((.53 + .24) / 2) = 1.95; r = 1.95 / sqrt(1.95^2 + 4) = .70). The second set of results refer to pictures of faces staying on the screen for 2 seconds. For 100% happy facial expressions, the tendency to correctly recognize pictures of happy faces was higher in the control group (d = (-.15 - -.33) / ((.49 + .12) / 2) = 0.93; r = 0.93 / sqrt(0.93^2 + 4) = .42). For 50% happy facial expressions, the tendency to incorrectly say pictures of non-happy faces (e.g., neutral) were happy was also high in the control group (d = -.26 - -.55 / ((.49 + .16) / 2) = 1.43; r = 1.43 / sqrt(1.43^2 + 4) = .58).

Two similar studies found a non-significant difference between a depressed group and control group on happy facial expression recognition, although the effect size point estimate were meaningful: 1 - (d = (92.2- 87.5) / ((13.4 + 8.4) / 2) = .43, r = .43 / sqrt(.43^2 + 4) = .21) (Leppanen et al., 2004); 2 - (d = ((.82 - .80) + (.82 - .78)) / 2) / ((.07 + .07 + .07 + .06) / 4) = .44, r = .44 / sqrt(.44^2 + 4) = .21) (Milders et al., 2010). In addition, one study found no difference between a depressed group and a control group on happiness facial expression recognition. In the first study, for happy faces, % accuracy was 68.7 in each group (d = 68.7 – 68.7 / ((22.4 + 21.6) / 2) = 0.00, r = 0.00) (Csukly et al., 2009). Three older studies did not report enough statistical information to calculate a correlation coefficient. One did not find any significant differences between happiness facial expression recognition for those with high anxiety (low well-being) and those with low anxiety (high well-being) (Surcinelli et al., 2006). The two other study did find significant differences between happiness facial expression recognition for those with high depression (low well-being) and those with low depression (high well-being) (Mikhailova et al., 1996; Rubinow & Post, 1992). 

Csukly, G., Czobor, P., Szily, E., Takács, B., & Simon, L. (2009). Facial expression recognition in depressed subjects: the impact of intensity level and arousal dimension. The Journal of Nervous and Mental Disease, 197(2), 98-103.

Demenescu, L. R., Kortekaas, R., den Boer, J. A., & Aleman, A. (2010). Impaired attribution of emotion to facial expressions in anxiety and major depression. PloS one, 5(12), e15058.

Leppänen, J. M., Milders, M., Bell, J. S., Terriere, E., & Hietanen, J. K. (2004). Depression biases the recognition of emotionally neutral faces. Psychiatry Research, 128(2), 123-133.

Mikhailova, E. S., Vladimirova, T. V., Iznak, A. F., Tsusulkovskaya, E. J., & Sushko, N. V. (1996). Abnormal recognition of facial expression of emotions in depressed patients with major depression disorder and schizotypal personality disorder. Biological Psychiatry, 40(8), 697-705.

Milders, M., Bell, S., Platt, J., Serrano, R., & Runcie, O. (2010). Stable expression recognition abnormalities in unipolar depression. Psychiatry Research, 179(1), 38-42.

Rubinow, D. R., & Post, R. M. (1992). Impaired recognition of affect in facial expression in depressed patients. Biological Psychiatry, 31(9), 947-953.

Surcinelli, P., Codispoti, M., Montebarocci, O., Rossi, N., & Baldaro, B. (2006). Facial emotion recognition in trait anxiety. Journal of Anxiety Disorders, 20(1), 110-117.

Surguladze, S. A., Young, A. W., Senior, C., Brébion, G., Travis, M. J., & Phillips, M. L. (2004). Recognition accuracy and response bias to happy and sad facial expressions in patients with major depression. Neuropsychology, 18(2), 212-218.

Toner, H. L., & Gates, G. R. (1985). Emotional traits and recognition of facial expression of emotion. Journal of Nonverbal Behavior, 9(1), 48-66.

Regarding the positive expression recognition hypothesis (i.e., Hypothesis 2), the large standardized effect size variability in the existing scientific literature makes it difficult to draw conclusions about what effect size to expect from the population underlying the present study. The larger effect sizes are likely a result of extreme group designs comparing individuals with a depression diagnosis and those without many symptoms. Since our study is not using an extreme groups design, we would not expect the larger correlations of r = .50 and above. Therefore, the statistical power for Hypothesis 2 was evaluated for the central range of zero-order correlations for studies using self-report measures: r = .10, r = .20, r = .30, and r = .40. In addition, minimum and maximum expected sample sizes were evaluated: 500 – (500 * .33) = 335 and 1000 – (1000 * .33) = 670. We assume a Type I error rate of .05.

Statistical Power (1 – β)	N = 335	N = 670
r = .10	.45	.74
r = .20	.96	.99
r = .30	.99	.99
r = .40	.99	.99
registration_responses.q15: After one semester/summer of data collection, if we do not have at least 500 participants, we will do another round of data collection the following semester/summer. We will continue data collection each semester/summer until we have at least 500 participants by the end of that semester/summer. Once we have more than 500 participants after the end of a semester/summer, data collection will stop.

Unstandardized indirect effects will equal A-path unstandardized regression coefficient * B-path unstandardized regression coefficient. Unstandardized total effects will equal Unstandardized indirect effect + Cprime-path (i.e., direct effects are equal to Cprime-path unstandardized regression coefficients). As a statistical sensitivity check, data analysis will also be conducted where all data for a participant will only be excluded if they fail all 6 attention check items.

registration_responses.q8.question: The study is an observational study without any variable manipulation. The study is cross-sectional and so involves only one timepoint. The study is online and participants will complete all study procedures through the Qualtrics platform on their computer. Participants will complete the study procedures in the following order: 1) half the questionnaires, 2) the facial expression stimuli, 3) the other half of the questionnaires, 4) demographics, 5) the pleasant video stimuli. A PDF of the Qualtrics survey is attached.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will be college students at a large, state university in the Midwest region of the United States. They will be compensated with course (extra) credit for their undergraduate psychology classes. Participants will be required to be 18 years old and literate in the English language. Students can be traditional or non-traditional students and can live on or off campus.
registration_responses.q16.question: No manipulated variables are involved in this study
registration_responses.q17.question:
Positive emotion reactivity will be measured by reactions to pleasant video stimuli. Participants will view two brief videos on their computer screen (~ 3 minutes each). The two videos will be randomized to prevent confounding by order effects. Before and after watching each video, participants will report how intensely they are currently experiencing 15 different emotions, with the 8 positive emotions being used (7 ordinal response options). I will refer to this as the state positive emotion questionnaire.

The 45*4 = 180 pictures will be randomized to prevent confounding by order effects. After seeing each picture, participants will report whether the facial expression is "pleasant" or "unpleasant" (2 binary response options).

Subjective happiness will be measured by the Subjective Happiness Scale questionnaire (7 ordinal response options).

I will refer to this as the trait positive affect questionnaire. Second, the Dispositional Positive Emotions scale which asks about general frequency and intensity of 7 different positive emotions with 7 ordinal response options.

Positive emotion reactivity will be quantified as the difference in state positive emotion from before and after the videos. The 7 response options for state positive emotion will be numerically coded from 0 to 6. Observed scores will be created by averaging the item response codes and then converting them to percentage of maximum possible (POMP) units to enhance interpretation. As a statistical sensitivity check, data analysis will also be conducted using raw difference scores.

Positive expression recognition will be quantified as minus the average percentage of happiness facial expression morph for pictures that the participant rates as pleasant. Each picture is a morph of a different facial expression, including happiness expression and various negative emotion expressions. Each picture has a percentage of happiness expression associated with it. These percentages will be averaged together, for those pictures that the participant rated as pleasant. The minus of the average percentage is used such that higher values correspond to greater positive expression recognition.

Item responses from each questionnaire will be used to create unit-weighted total scores. The response options will be numerically coded from 0 to 6 for the 7 response option questionnaires (Riverside Life Satisfaction Scale, Subjective Happiness Scale, trait positive affect) and 0 to 3 for the 4 response options questionnaires (Center for Epidemiological Study of Depression – Depressed Affect subscale). Any negatively valanced items will be reverse coded. Total scores will be created by averaging the item response codes and then converted them to percentage of maximum possible (POMP) units to enhance interpretation.

Regarding the Dispositional Positive Emotions scale, because the original scale development paper found a wide range of inter-subscale correlations from r = .05 to r = .75, we will conduct psychometric tests of the questionnaire to determine an appropriate total score (e.g., exclude certain subscales). Specifically, we will use the omega hierarchical reliability coefficient from a bifactor model to make determinations.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Structural equation modeling (SEM) will be conducted with the `lavaan` R package. Three separate models will be tested: 1) positive emotion reactivity as the predictor, 2) positive expression recognition as the predictor, 3) both positive emotion reactivity and positive expression recognition as simultaneous predictors with the two different measures of trait positive affect: 1) Trait positive affect questionnaire, 2) Dispositional Positive Emotions scale, resulting in six total SEMs. Neither of the predictors will have a measurement model, but rather be singular manifest variables. The mediator of trait positive affect will also not have a measurement model and be a singular manifest variable. The outcome of general well-being will have a latent measurement model with life satisfaction, subjective happiness, and depressed mood as three manifest indicators.

A-paths, B-paths, and Cprime-paths will be specified. No covaried errors between the general well-being indicators and the mediator or predictor(s) will be specified. The estimator will be full information maximum likelihood (FIML) to account for any missing data and confidence intervals will be computed via bootstrapping (including for the indirect effects). Model fit will be assessed via the CFI, TLI, RSMEA, and SRMR. Re-specification based on modification indices will only be considered if a model fit index is less than the following (arbitrary) cutoffs: CFI < .80; TLI < .80; RMSEA > .15; SRMR > .15. The author has a preference for sticking with a priori specified SEM models and not re-specifying them based on modification indices – hence the relatively low model fit index cutoffs.

attributes.title: The effect of search goal specificity on attentional capture by emotion
attributes.withdrawal_justification:
A major change has been made to the stopping rule for this experiment, due to the change of dependent variable.

Data with timestamp will be uploaded to confirm that the data collected for this project was collected after withdrawal of the current registration, and after the approval of the revised pre-registration.
